entry.title: Re: Notifications are not being sent on status changes tr...
entry.content:
It depends where is your script running.

Are you running it from Global script due to some trigger, then you may have to call notifications manually or trigger via API.

Otherwise if its done via workflow action, then you need to attach the notification to the action in the workflow matrix, and also please check if you forgot to add the email list into your notification. Because that could also be the reason why its not working.

entry.title: Forms Service by Adobe (BTP): Persistent "No client with requested id" Error after Configuration
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am seeking assistance with a persistent authentication issue while setting up SAP Forms Service by Adobe in the BTP Cloud Foundry environment.

Despite following the standard setup documentation, I am unable to access the Template Store UI. I consistently receive the following error: No client with requested id: sb-ads-xsappname!b65488

What I have configured so far:

  1. Entitlements: Added "Forms Service by Adobe" and "Forms Service by Adobe API" (free plans).

  2. Subscription: Successfully subscribed to "Forms Service by Adobe" (default plan).

  3. Instance: Created a service instance for "Forms Service by Adobe API" in my space.

  4. Role Collections: Created and assigned a Role Collection containing ADSAdmin and TemplateStoreAdmin.

  5. Direct Access: I have tried accessing the UI via the "Go to Application" link and via the direct URL found in the destination configuration.

Steps taken to resolve the issue (but failed):

  • Verified that the Application Identifier in the Role Collection matches the subscription.

  • Unsubscribed and re-subscribed to force a new OAuth registration.

  • Cleared browser cache and used Incognito/Guest modes.

  • Waited for propagation (over 30 minutes).

It seems the XSUAA service is still looking for a specific client ID (!b65488) that perhaps isn't being correctly mapped or registered in the Trust Configuration.

System Details:

  • Environment: Cloud Foundry

  • Region: US10

  • Identity Provider: Default and Custom

Has anyone encountered this specific mismatch before? Is there a way to force a refresh of the OAuth2 clients in the subaccount, or is this a backend issue that requires an SAP Support ticket?

Thank you for your help!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Mass update journal entry G/L item field ‚ÄúReference 1‚Äù
entry.content:
There is no standard app to mass change this field for posted G/L items. The supported option is the SOAP API ‚ÄúJournal Entry ‚Äì Change (Asynchronous)‚Äù (JournalEntryBulkChangeRequest_In), which allows bulk changes of journal entry header/item data for documents with entry views. If the field is not changeable, the API rejects the request (for example: ‚Äúfield is not open for input‚Äù). Processing can be monitored via AIF / Message Dashboard.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/c3833c31e7724a79b23e4273290f3e2e.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

entry.title: Re: Item text disappears in edit mode
entry.content: When choosing 'Edit', the journal entry shifts from Ledger View to Entry View automatically. Please ensure that the correct view is being used before and after entering edit mode to ensure consistent information is persisted.

entry.title: How can I use Google Tag manager in Workzone?
entry.content:
I want to track outbound clicks from my Workzone site since it's acting as a front-end to a SuccessFactors app that supports business processes. I want to compare how many users are using the guidance on workzone to complete SF tasks.

I've had Google analytics on the site since launch using the 3rd party analytics option in the workzone admin console. Great. 

Google Tag Manager is the best practice approach to tracking outbound clicks, but there's no way to add the GTM container snippet to workzone which is necessary for this.

How can I use GTM in Workzone?

GA's native outbound link tracking (i.e. not using GTM) would have been good enough had the GA event report returned link_text. It doesn't, although it should according to spec, probably because of the complex messy html that workzone writes.

entry.title: Re: Personas SP20 - after upgrade screen display inconsis...
entry.content: Background: We are on Personas 3.0 SP18, Personas are used to enhance EWM_MOBGUI screens for /SCWM/RFUI application. We use only 1 flavor assigned through security role and FlavorID in /PERSONAS/ADMIN is matching with FlavorID on this displayed screen (we use inspect element). We have 2 scripts a) to change background color of an active field b) play audio beeps and the scripts are firing good. Application has been deployed 3 warehouses and are working as expected in DEV, QA and Prod environment. Additional info: /SCWM/RFUI screen fields are configurable, meaning, the number of fields displayed on the screen (mobile) can/are controlled by configuration. Symptoms: We were building 4th Warehouse. Already existing flavor was updated with new application screens for 4th Warehouse. Performance was bad during test, so DEV was upgraded to SP19 and then to SP20, while QA is in SP19. Some of the application screens on display doesnt adapt flavor, raw screen is displayed on load, however, with superuser role, click P, select original screen and then again select the created flavor then displays the screen correctly. Also script are not triggering any more. Question: Some application screen share same screen program name and screen number, but the 4th Warehouse, have more fields to display. How does Personas determine positions for this new fields? or if some fields were removed, how does Personas handle the removed/suppressed fields? Also both the scripts are not triggering for the 4th Warehouse(triggers for other 3 warehouses. There are NO failures noticed in security trace. Is it possible Personas is storing organizational elements (like Plant number, Warehouse number etc)?

entry.title: 2602 Early Release Series for SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network releases
entry.content:
Sign up now for the 2602 Early Release Series

Follow this blog to receive notification of new series as soon as registration opens.

SAP strives to equip our customers and partners with valuable release readiness resources for each SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network quarterly release.

 

Early Release Series

The Early Release Series webcasts cover features planned for the upcoming SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network quarterly release.  This platform, available to customers and partners, has a clear mission: deliver an interactive forum to engage with SAP product experts providing simple, direct answers to your most pressing questions.  There is a different session for each product area with content tailored for the specific audience:

  • Supplier Management & Risk
  • Procure to Pay
  • Source to Contract
  • Business Network

If you want to learn more and actively engage with SAP subject matter experts, we encourage you to participate in these informative sessions.  Register now!

Quarterly Release Communications

Notice of upcoming quarterly releases will be communicated to Buyer customers three weeks prior to the release date.  Suppliers receive notice two weeks prior.  Releases are communicated via email notification (look for subject line starting with: Advance Release Notice).

Anyone from your organization that has chosen to subscribe to product notifications will receive these announcements. 

The release calendar for SAP Business Network  and release calendar SAP Ariba Applications identify release timing several quarters in advance.

Where to find out more details?

On demand replays of webcasts from completed quarterly releases can be consumed from Release Readiness Resources: Webcast Archive Page

  • Enabling your technical teams for your UX journey

You can find the accelerators by selecting the tag User Experience in your preferred SAP Activate roadmap viewer at https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer. You will find them in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP Cloud ERP Private roadmaps for New Installation, System Conversion, Selective Data Transition, and Upgrades. 

Hint: Most advice in the accelerators is also relevant to customers using SAP S/4HANA on-premise.  For use of SAP Business AI in SAP S/4HANA on-premise refer to SAP Note 3632703 - Enabling Joule for On-Premise systems

In SAP Activate, you can also search for accelerators using keyword UX Adoption or try Joule in SAP Activate. 

Example screenshot: Using the tag User Experience in the SAP Cloud ERP Private - System Conversion roadmap to find UX Adoption accelerators. Links to the accelerators are highlighted.

In this blog post you will find:

  • What‚Äôs New/Changed highlights
  • Where to find the accelerators ‚Äì step by step
  • FAQ

What‚Äôs New/Changed Highlights

All updated accelerators are marked as version December 2025.

Example screenshot: Title slide of the workshop template UX Adoption: Establish the Business Value of UX . The version December 2025 is highlighted and appears below the title.

All 6 of the UX Adoption Workshop Templates have been updated.  The UX Adoption workshops encourage an iterative approach to UX Adoption so you can manage the pace of change.

  • All workshop templates are provided in ready-to-use Microsoft Powerpoint PPTX format.
  • All workshop templates now include a Content Summary slide so you don‚Äôt miss out on any of the good stuff in the Additional Resources section.

Example screenshot:  Content Summary slide of the workshop template UX Adoption: Establish the Business Value of UX .  Highlighted are in the Additional Resources are: Major points and demonstration hints; Going beyond SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition; Persona templates for pre-/post- workshop homework; UX Value Goals Deeper Dive slides with AI-assisted examples;  Information for the Technical Team.

 

Summary of Workshop Templates - purpose and major changes:

  • Establish the Business Value of UX ‚Äì Introduce SAP Fiori to your business stakeholders and technical teams. Links to the latest demo videos (including free SAP Learning videos) are included so you can demo the latest SAP Fiori user experience like a pro!  You will also find tips to get your technical team started on supporting your UX adoption journey. 

 

  • UX Strategy and Guiding Principles ‚Äì Grow awareness of launchpad features that apply across most apps and processes, including SAP Joule and SAP Mobile Start.  Quickly build consensus on which features to use now/next/later.  Now extended with latest available features such as SAP Joule, the Unified Navigation Bar, Manage News app, collaboration using Microsoft Teams, and App Inspector for easy troubleshooting.

 

  • Scope the Future ‚Äì Scope and evaluate apps and features that fit with your business value goals. Now with advice on how to match SAP Business AI use cases - including Joule ‚Äì to your desired business outcomes. You will also find updated a step-by-step guide for evaluating apps in 5-10 minutes.  Get tips on using no-code/low-code upgrade-safe Clean Core key user extensions - such as Adapt UI ‚Äì to check what‚Äôs easy to change for your selected apps.  Includes Clean core references, such as SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì What is Key User Extensibility and Who are your Key Users for key users and SAP Note  3578329 - Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility for developers.

 

  • Envision the Future ‚Äì Estimate extension effort, refine your scope, and agree on business benefits to highlight to your users.  Updated for AI effort considerations.

 

  • Design your Launchpad Layout ‚Äì Make changes easy for your users to adopt.  Updated with the latest features of spaces and pages layouts.

 

  • Review Business Benefits Realization ‚Äì Measure usage, capture adoption learnings, and trigger the next iteration of UX Adoption. Now with tips on using Early Watch for usage metrics; plus, tracking process improvements with SAP Signavio Process Insights.

Other updated UX Adoption accelerators:

  • SAP User Experience Strategy Template ‚Äì Document your UX Adoption decisions made in your workshops. Capture your agreed business aims, high-level direction, architecture, phases, and progress.  You will see helpful examples and starting points. Now updated with more guidance on SAP Build Work Zone architecture options; SAP Business AI considerations and references; software accessibility (e.g. WCAG) compliance considerations; example timelines for small vs larger adoption projects; latest launchpad content and support tooling; app lifecycle and transport management; and managing security authorizations for your SAP Fiori apps.

 Hint: The User Experience Strategy Template is provided in Microsoft Word DOCX format to get you started quickly.  

  • UX Adoption: UX Value Goal App Selection Guides ‚Äì Select apps and features that match your business goals. All guides now contain SAP Business AI use cases. Guides now come with examples from the latest SAP S/4HANA 2025 apps, and launchpad features such as integration with Microsoft Teams chat/tabs/contacts; personalizing My Home dashboards with Add Card to Insights; and using the new list view in the SAP Fiori apps reference library to understand what‚Äôs available.  

The UX Value Goal App Selection guides are a set of 9 guides to help you match apps and features to your business goals. They include standard and custom-built options for each value goal. 

  • Be more MOBILE ‚Äì do more on more device types (tablets, phones, wearables, etc.)
  • GUIDE me better ‚Äì help me navigate my day
  • COLLABORATE better ‚Äì support working across onshore/offshore teams, for example using Microsoft Teams Integration.
  • RESPOND faster ‚Äì use Joule skills to speed up simple tasks, get fast info from search
  • REACT faster ‚Äì get notified of business situations early
  • Be more PROACTIVE ‚Äì use analytics and predictive models to trigger action
  • Be more AUTOMATED ‚Äì use Joule agents to speed up complex tasks
  • Be more ADAPTABLE ‚Äì make the most of Clean Core techniques to adapt to changing business needs

Hint: The UX Value Goal App Selection Guides are provide as a zipped file of 9 short PDFs. 

And finally:

  • Quick Guide for Fit Evaluation ‚Äì Find the easy ways to adjust apps and features to your business needs. Shift your business stakeholder (and project team) mindsets towards: using AI every day;  working well with SAP Fiori; and transitioning at your pace from SAP GUI.  Now with improved advice based on recent customer project experiences and including SAP Business AI. 

Hint: The Quick Guide for Fit Evaluation is provided as a PDF.

 

Where to find the UX Adoption Accelerators ‚Äì Step by Step

You will find the accelerators referenced in several of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition roadmaps.  

Find all the roadmaps in SAP for Me in the SAP Activate Roadmap Viewer at: https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer

Select Explore All Roadmaps to find and mark your favourites.

Example: SAP Activate Road Map Viewer page showing the Explore All Road Maps button. Favorite roadmaps are shown for SAP Activate SAP Cloud ERP  Private.

 

The SAP Activate roadmaps for SAP Cloud ERP Private (i.e. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition ) contain many UX Adoption accelerators and content tasks.

Select the tag User Experience to find the UX Adoption accelerators.

Example screenshot showing the Accelerators tab in the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - System Conversion roadmap. The tag User Experience is selected in the left-hand pane - and includes a count of the accelerators found. In the right pane the accelerators are listed by Activate phase.

 

The accelerators are shown by phase. Simply select the links to download the accelerators you want to use.

Example screenshot highlighting the links to the accelerators in the Accelerators tab of the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - System Conversion road map.

You can also search across SAP Activate to find accelerators using SAP Joule. You can get quick information on related tasks, and AI-powered insights on making the most of these accelerators.

Example screenshot of showing using the SAP Activate search with keyword ux adoption.  AI-Powered Insights are shown for the selected roadmap giving quick guidance on how to use the accelerators, followed by the Search Results with links to accelerators.

 

FAQ

Do I have to wait for our next project to get value out of the accelerators?

No. You can use the content whenever you need to build awareness, encourage further adoption, and plan next steps.

Do I have to be using SAP Activate methodology to use these accelerators?

No. 

How you run your project is up to you and your partner.  Some SAP partners have their own methodology based on SAP Activate. 

Some customers use simple mini-sprints to grow adoption - you can example of a mini-sprint plan in the SAP User Experience Strategy Template. 

However you run your project, these accelerators are provided to help you confidently introduce User Experience, collaboratively make UX adoption decisions with your business stakeholders, and successfully bring a new way of working to your business users.

Do I have to run a workshop to use the templates?

No. For example:

  • You can select slides and demo videos from Establish the Business Value of UX to explain SAP Fiori to your long-term SAP GUI users.
  • You can refer to the App Selection Guide Be more MOBILE to find what apps make sense to use on smaller devices
  • You can refer to the App Selection Guide Be more AUTOMATED to understand how to find available SAP Joule Agents and what you need to create custom-built Joule Agents.

Can I get AI to help me select apps?

Yes!

In the UX Adoption: Scope the Future Workshop Template you will find some brief examples of using SAP Joule for Consultants to get advice. For example, ‚Äúis there a Fiori app for <this task> in SAP S/4HANA <your release‚Äù.

 

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You‚Äôll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG and Customer Care team.

entry.title: Re: Workzone hide card dynamically
entry.content:
Hi,

Maybe you can try to implement conditional rendering that completely removes the card from the DOM when no news is available. This is a sample code from Joule.

// Card Controller - Component Card Implementation
sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/integration/Extension"
], function (Extension) {
    "use strict";

    var NewsCardExtension = Extension.extend("custom.news.NewsCardExtension");

    NewsCardExtension.prototype.init = function () {
        Extension.prototype.init.apply(this, arguments);
        this.checkNewsAvailability();
    };

    NewsCardExtension.prototype.checkNewsAvailability = function () {
        // Fetch news data
        this.getNewsData().then(function(newsData) {
            if (!newsData || newsData.length === 0) {
                // Remove card completely from DOM
                this.hideCardCompletely();
            } else {
                // Render card with news content
                this.renderNewsCard(newsData);
            }
        }.bind(this));
    };

    NewsCardExtension.prototype.hideCardCompletely = function () {
        var oCard = this.getCard();
        var oCardDomRef = oCard.getDomRef();
        if (oCardDomRef && oCardDomRef.parentNode) {
            oCardDomRef.parentNode.removeChild(oCardDomRef);
        }
    };

    return NewsCardExtension;
});

 Best Regards,

Aqua

entry.title: Re: Dump CX_SY_REF_IS_INITIAL in CREATE_FS_TOOLBAR of CL_SALV_GUI_SLIS_FACTORY in SE84
entry.content:
This is a known SAP standard bug in ABAP 7.58 SP01.
The short dump CX_SY_REF_IS_INITIAL in CREATE_FS_TOOLBAR of CL_SALV_GUI_SLIS_FACTORY (triggered from SE84) is not a custom issue.

SAP has confirmed and fixed it via correction notes.

Correct fix sequence:

  • SAP Note 3433027 ‚Äì ALV: HS Grid/List and Functions Toolbar ‚Äì Correction Package

  • SAP Note 3433207 ‚Äì Technical correction (auto‚Äëinstalls dependencies)

  • SAP Note 3437774 ‚Äì Functional changes (tight dependency with 3433207)

‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Notes 3433207 and 3437774 are tightly coupled and must be installed together.

After implementing these notes, the SE84 screen opens normally and the dump no longer occurs.

SAP has also published a KBA referencing this defect:

  • KBA 3703259 ‚Äì ALV: OBJECTS_OBJREF_NOT_ASSIGNED_NO dump for CL_SALV_GUI_SLIS_FACTORY in SE84

So the resolution is simply to apply the above SAP Notes.

entry.title: AA347 Error When Posting MIRO in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‚Äì FI-AA Fiscal Year Not Updated
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am attempting to post a vendor invoice using transaction MIRO, and I am receiving the following error message:

‚ÄúCannot post to fixed assets in company code XXXX and fiscal year 2026.
Message No.: AA347
Diagnosis: The fiscal year change has not yet been performed in Fixed Asset Accounting for company code XXXX.
Procedure: Verify the reference date.‚Äù

This issue started after migrating to SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

The fiscal year 2025 has already been closed. However, I observed the following:

  • Transaction AJRW is not available in the system.

  • In transaction OAAQ, the fiscal year for the company code still shows 2025.

  • All functional checks were performed (AJAB, OB52, OAAQ, posting dates).

  • The root cause identified is that the FI-AA technical fiscal year in table T093C (field LGJAHR ‚Äì Current Fiscal Year) remains in 2025, although it should be 2026.

Due to this inconsistency, the MIRO posting cannot be completed.

I kindly request SAP Support to realign the FI-AA fiscal year to 2026 in order to resolve this issue and allow the MIRO posting to be processed successfully.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Ronald Onton

entry.title: Connecting SAP Sales Cloud V2 to a Standalone SAP Analytics Cloud - A Practical Alternative
entry.content:
The Customer Challenge

A customer approached me with what seemed like a straightforward request: "We want to analyze our SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 data in SAP Analytics Cloud."

Their situation was common for mid-sized companies adopting SAP's CX portfolio:

  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 was live and running well
  • SAP Analytics Cloud was licensed separately (not the embedded version)
  • No SAP BTP subscription yet, it wasn't part of the initial scope
  • No SAP Integration Suite same reason
  • No SAP Datasphere, they wanted to avoid another data platform

The goal was simple: import Accounts, Contacts, and Opportunities into SAC for custom dashboards that combined CX data with data from other sources

What SAP Officially Recommends

Before building anything custom, I researched SAP's official guidance. The recommended architecture for Sales Cloud V2 analytics integration involves:

  1. SAP Datasphere as a central data layer
  2. SAP Integration Suite for event-driven data replication
  3. SAP Advanced Event Mesh (optional but recommended) for resilience

SAP published a detailed two-part blog series on this: Event-Driven Data Integration from SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 to SAP Datasphere

This architecture is elegant and production-grade. It's also significant additional investment for a customer who just wants to run a few reports.

Cost Implications

The official path requires more than you might expect:

ComponentStatus for this Customer
SAP DatasphereNot licensed (‚Ç¨‚Ç¨‚Ç¨/month)
SAP Integration SuiteNot licensed (‚Ç¨‚Ç¨/month)
SAP BTP subscriptionNot available
Implementation effortSignificant (weeks)


For a customer with ~24,000 accounts who wants three dashboards, this felt like using a sledgehammer to crack a nut.

The Obvious First Attempt: SAC's Built-in Connectors

SAC has connectors for various SAP sources. Surely there's something for Sales Cloud?

Attempt 1: The "SAP Cloud for Customer" Connector

SAC includes a dedicated connector called "SAP Cloud for Customer" that works beautifully with the older C4C (Cloud for Customer) system. It connects to OData services like:

https://<tenant>/sap/c4c/odata/v1/c4codataapi/AccountCollection

The problem: Sales Cloud V2 is not C4C. So the OData connector won‚Äôt work:

Attempt 2: The Generic OData Connector

SAC also has a generic "OData Services" connector. Maybe that works?

The problem: Sales Cloud V2 doesn't expose OData endpoints. The APIs on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub are REST, not OData.

GET /sap/c4c/api/v1/account-service/accounts ‚Üê REST, not OData
GET /sap/c4c/api/v1/contact-service/contacts ‚Üê REST, not OData

Attempt 3: Live Connection

Sales Cloud V2 has embedded SAC capabilities. Could we establish a live connection?

The problem: The embedded analytics are designed for "embedded" use cases. Connecting a standalone SAC tenant to Sales Cloud V2 for custom reporting seems to be... let's say "not a focus area" right now.

I opened a support ticket to clarify the expected behavior and it was put in development after a little back and forth.

The Hidden Challenge: Real-Time vs. Import

At this point, I had to step back and discuss architecture with the customer.

Even if a direct connector existed, there are implications to consider:

 

ApproachProsCons
Live ConnectionAlways current dataQuery performance depends on source; cannot combine with other data sources easily
Import ConnectionFast queries; can blend with other sourcesData has latency; storage costs

The customer wanted to combine Sales Cloud V2 data with SAP S/4HANA data in the same dashboard. This essentially requires import connections for both sources, plus a data model in SAC that joins them.

Real-time was never really an option as they needed data at rest in SAP Analytics Cloud 

The Solution: A Lightweight REST-to-OData Proxy

Since the customer had:

  • No appetite for SAP Datasphere
  • No CPI license
  • A clear, limited scope (three entity types)
  • Tolerance for daily data refresh (not real-time)

I proposed building a thin proxy server that:

  1. Authenticates with Sales Cloud V2
  2. Fetches data via REST APIs
  3. Transforms responses to OData format
  4. Exposes endpoints that SAC can consume natively

Architecture

This sounds straightforward... until you start building it...

Challenge 1: The 999 vs. 1000 Mismatch

This one deserves its own section because it‚Äôs so unexpected.

SAP Sales Cloud V2 REST APIs have a maximum page size of 999 records. You can request $top=999, but not more.

SAP Analytics Cloud OData import has a minimum batch size of 1000 records.

Yes, you read that correctly. The source maxes out at 999. The target starts at 1000. I'll admit I stared at the logs for longer than I'd like to admit before I realized what was happening. The first 999 records imported perfectly. Then nothing. It took me a while to connect that SAC was waiting for a 1000-record batch that would never arrive.

The Solution

The proxy implements on-demand parallel fetching:

async function fetchAllRecords(entityType: string): Promise<any[]> {
  // Get first page to determine total count
  const firstPage = await fetchFromSalesCloud(entityType, {
    $top: 999,
    $skip: 0
  });
  
  if (firstPage.value.length < 999) {
    // All records fit in first page
    return firstPage.value;
  }
  
  // Calculate remaining pages and fetch in parallel
  const totalEstimate = firstPage.totalCount || 10000;
  const remainingPages = Math.ceil((totalEstimate - 999) / 999);
  
  const pagePromises = Array.from({ length: remainingPages }, (_, i) => 
    fetchFromSalesCloud(entityType, {
      $top: 999,
      $skip: 999 * (i + 1)
    })
  );
  
  const results = await Promise.all(pagePromises);
  return [firstPage.value, ...results.map(r => r.value)].flat();
}

The proxy fetches pages in parallel (not sequentially), caches the combined result, and serves it to SAC in appropriately sized batches. The cache has a configurable TTL (e.g., 1 hour) and automatically refreshes on the next request after expiry.

Challenge 2: Nested Objects and Flattening

Sales Cloud V2 returns nicely structured JSON with nested objects:

{
  "value": [{
    "accountId": "A001",
    "accountName": "ACME Corp",
    "primaryContact": {
      "contactId": "C001",
      "firstName": "John",
      "lastName": "Doe"
    },
    "addresses": [
      { "type": "BILL_TO", "city": "Berlin" },
      { "type": "SHIP_TO", "city": "Munich" }
    ]
  }]
}

SAC‚Äôs OData importer cannot handle this. The SAP Help documentation states clearly: Embedded Complex types are not supported.

The Solution

The proxy must flatten nested structures into separate entity sets:

/odata/Accounts         ‚Üí Flat account records
/odata/Contacts         ‚Üí Flat contact records  
/odata/AccountAddresses ‚Üí One row per address, linked by accountId

Challenge 3: REST APIs Behave Differently Than OData

Coming from the OData world, I expected certain conventions:

  • $filter for filtering
  • $select for field selection
  • $expand for related entities
  • Standardized metadata endpoint

Sales Cloud V2 REST APIs have their own conventions:

  • Different query parameter syntax
  • No $metadata endpoint
  • Pagination via custom headers or response properties

The proxy needs to translate between these worlds, implementing just enough OData semantics to satisfy SAC‚Äôs importer.

Challenge 4: The $skip 10,000 Limit

Just when you think you‚Äôve handled pagination, there‚Äôs another surprise waiting for datasets with more than 10,000 records.

Sales Cloud V2 returns an error if $skip is 10,000 or greater.

// This works
GET /accounts?$top=999&$skip=9000  ‚úÖ

// This fails
GET /accounts?$top=999&$skip=10000  ‚ùå Error!

So even if you‚Äôve cleverly worked around the 999 page size limit, you hit a wall at record 10,001. Simple offset-based pagination ($skip) just stops working.

The Solution

Instead of offset-based pagination, the proxy uses keyset pagination with $skiptoken:

// src/constants.ts
export const SC_MAX_SKIP = 10000;

// When approaching the skip limit, switch to skiptoken
async function fetchWithKeysetPagination(entityType: string): Promise<any[]> {
  const allRecords: any[] = [];
  let nextLink: string | null = buildInitialUrl(entityType);
  
  while (nextLink) {
    const response = await fetch(nextLink);
    const data = await response.json();
    
    allRecords.push(...data.value);
    
    // Use the skiptoken from the response for next page
    nextLink = data['@odata.nextLink'] || null;
  }
  
  return allRecords;
}

Keyset pagination uses a token (typically based on the last record‚Äôs ID or timestamp) rather than a numeric offset. This approach:

  • Has no upper limit on the number of records
  • Is actually more performant than large offsets
  • Is the pattern SAP recommends for large datasets

If you have more than 10,000 records in any entity, you must use $skiptoken-based pagination. Simple $skip won‚Äôt cut it.

Implementation Notes

Technology Choice

I built the proxy with:

  • Node.js + Fastify: Lightweight, fast, excellent TypeScript support
  • On-demand caching: No scheduled jobs; cache fills dynamically on first request
  • Docker deployment: Runs on any container platform (I use Coolify on a VPS)

This is a production-ready setup. The proxy has been running reliably for the customer with no issues.

Smart Caching: On-Demand Parallel Fetching

Rather than running scheduled batch jobs, the proxy uses an on-demand approach:

  1. First page served instantly: When SAC requests data, the proxy immediately returns the first page (up to 999 records) from Sales Cloud V2
  2. Parallel fetching in background: While SAC processes the first page, the proxy fetches remaining pages in parallel
  3. Cache populated for subsequent requests: By the time SAC requests page 2, the data is already cached
async function handleODataRequest(req: Request): Promise<Response> {
  // Check cache first
  if (cache.has(entityType) && !cache.isExpired(entityType)) {
    return serveFromCache(entityType, req.query);
  }
  
  // Fetch first page immediately
  const firstPage = await fetchPage(entityType, 0, 999);
  
  // Start parallel fetching of remaining pages (non-blocking)
  fetchRemainingPagesInBackground(entityType, firstPage.totalCount);
  
  // Return first page immediately
  return formatAsOData(firstPage);
}

This approach has several advantages:

  • No unnecessary background jobs: Data is only fetched when actually needed
  • Fast initial response: User doesn‚Äôt wait for full dataset
  • Self-healing cache: Expired cache automatically refreshes on next request

Optional: Deploying to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry

If you already have a BTP subscription with available credits, deploying there can make sense. You‚Äôre using infrastructure you‚Äôre already paying for. The migration is straightforward:

Standalone Setup Cloud Foundry Setup

Environment variables for credentialsDestination Service binding
In-memory cachePostgreSQL Hyperscaler Option (free tier available)
Direct HTTP endpointXSUAA + AppRouter

Why PostgreSQL if you move to BTP?

On a single-container deployment (VPS e.g. with Coolify), in-memory caching works perfectly. But Cloud Foundry typically runs multiple app instances for high availability. If you need persistence across instances, PostgreSQL Hyperscaler Option is the lightweight choice. It has a free tier (since November 2025) and requires no additional management.

The additional effort for Cloud Foundry deployment is roughly:

  • Add mta.yaml with service bindings (~1 hour)
  • Configure Destination Service for Sales Cloud V2 credentials (~30 min)
  • Add XSUAA for authentication (~1 hour)
  • Test and deploy (~2 hours)

Total: Less than one additional day if you decide BTP is the right fit.

Don‚Äôt just default to BTP just because it‚Äôs SAP. Evaluate what you already have and what makes sense for your situation. A ‚Ç¨5/month VPS running Docker might be exactly right for your use case.

OData Response Format

SAC expects OData V2or V4 responses. The minimum viable format:

{
  "d": {
    "results": [
      { "AccountID": "A001", "AccountName": "ACME Corp", ... },
      { "AccountID": "A002", "AccountName": "Globex", ... }
    ]
  }
}

Plus a $metadata endpoint returning EDMX that describes your entity types.

Authentication

Sales Cloud V2 supports:

  • Basic Authentication (simplest for server-to-server)
  • OAuth 2.0 (more secure, recommended for production)

The proxy stores credentials securely and handles token refresh for OAuth.

Results

After implementing the proxy:

  • SAC successfully imports Accounts, Contacts, and Opportunities
  • Data refreshes nightly via scheduled import
  • Customer can blend CX data with S/4HANA data in unified dashboards
  • No additional SAP platform licenses required
  • Total implementation time: ~2 days

When This Approach Makes Sense

The right solution depends on what you have and what you need. Here‚Äôs how I think about it:

A lightweight proxy makes sense when:

  • Limited scope (specific entities, not the entire data model)
  • Import/batch refresh is acceptable (not real-time requirements)
  • You don‚Äôt have Datasphere or CPI licensed and don‚Äôt need them for other use cases
  • You want to validate the integration quickly before investing in bigger infrastructure

Datasphere + CPI makes sense when:

  • You need event-driven, near real-time data replication
  • You‚Äôre integrating many entity types with complex relationships
  • You already have Datasphere or CPI licensed then use what you‚Äôre paying for
  • You have a broader data strategy where Datasphere is the central hub anyway

The key question: What do you already have, and does this use case justify adding more?

SAP‚Äôs platforms are excellent, no question! But sometimes a focused solution that solves exactly your problem is better than pulling in the big guns for a straightforward requirement.

Lessons Learned

1. Don‚Äôt Assume SAP Products Integrate Seamlessly

Sales Cloud V2 and SAC are both modern SAP cloud products. The integration gap exists because V2‚Äôs move away from OData wasn‚Äôt accompanied by a new native SAC connector (yet).

2. Check API Patterns Before Committing to Architecture

The shift from OData to REST in Sales Cloud V2 is documented, but easy to miss if you‚Äôre coming from C4C experience. Always verify on api.sap.com.

3. Test with Realistic Data Volumes

The 999/1000 mismatch only surfaces with more than 999 records. Demo systems with 50 accounts work fine. Production breaks.

4. Use What You Have, Validate What You Need

The official architecture is powerful. But if you don‚Äôt already have Datasphere and CPI licensed, ask yourself: does this specific use case justify adding them? Sometimes a focused solution that solves exactly your problem is the right call. You can always scale up later if requirements grow.

What‚Äôs Next?

I‚Äôve published a reference implementation on GitHub that demonstrates the core patterns:

  • REST-to-OData transformation
  • Parallel fetching with caching
  • The 999‚Üí1000 batch bridging logic
  • Keyset pagination with $skiptoken for large datasets (>10k records)

üëâ GitHub: SAP Sales Cloud V2 OData Proxy

A note on scope: The repository shows how the solution works, but doesn‚Äôt include everything from my production implementation. Some aspects are tied to specific client configurations that I can‚Äôt share. If you‚Äôre facing a similar challenge and want help getting to production faster, feel free to reach out.

If you‚Äôve built something similar or found a better approach I‚Äôd love to hear about it in the comments.

entry.title: SAP Joule implementation in an S/4HANA private cloud 3 system landscape
entry.content:
While most customers choose to activate and run SAP Joule in a single-system S/4HANA Private Cloud landscape, I had the opportunity to implement it across a complete three-system landscape‚ÄîDEV, QAS, and PRD. This approach brought additional complexity in terms of transport, configuration consistency, and cross-system validation, but it also ensured a more robust, production-ready deployment. Successfully enabling Joule in a full landscape setup is not just a technical task; it reflects a deeper understanding of SAP architecture, governance, and best practices. Delivering this implementation end-to-end has been a noteworthy achievement in my SAP journey. 

Sharing this experience is important because a three-system setup brings its own challenges, and I hope this blog will make the process clearer and easier for anyone working in a similar landscape. 

The steps for implementing Joule remain the same across landscapes, but there are several important considerations that need to be planned in advance before starting the implementation in a customer environment. 

Let‚Äôs get started. 

Architecture diagram 

1. BTP subaccounts and Cloud identity service 

For non-production systems (development and quality systems), we need to create two different subaccounts for each to enable the required Joule and Work Zone subscriptions and services. This separation helps maintain a clear landscape structure aligned with the backend systems.  However, it is recommended to use a common subaccount for the Cloud Identity Services (CIS) tenant, as it has only one connectivity service, and identity management should remain centralized for consistent user provisioning and authentication across both environments, and we are using non prod IAS tenants for both. 

 Tip: We can also integrate Joule without creating a separate subaccount for CIS by including CIS in the individual DEV and QA subaccounts, but in that case we need to create the RFC for the identity service from the DEV subaccount for the QA system by pointing this RFC to the QA system used when configuring the source system in IAS. 

2. SAP roles assignment to users 

Since Joule-specific capabilities are embedded within certain standard SAP roles, it‚Äôs important to ensure that end users who will be accessing Joule have these roles assigned. Without the required role assignments, users will not be able to utilize Joule‚Äôs features fully. For most customers, users already have their standard Fiori roles assigned based on their functional area‚Äîfor example, a finance user typically has all the roles required for their day-to-day activities. 

Tip: Get a list of all the roles from the customer security team and make sure these roles are exposed to BTP in all three systems. It‚Äôs better to involve the security team here to get this step done. 

3. Technical and business catalog creation 

This step must be carried out in the development system. The technical and business catalogs required for the QA and PRD systems will also be created in DEV and then transported to the respective systems as part of the normal transport process. During production cutover activities make sure the transports for catalogs are moved to production systems. 

 Tip: If we are configuring Joule in unit test clients other than the DEV client, create catalogs and roles in the development client and then create a client copy transport to the Joule configuration client in the development system. The same applies for any other developments as well. 

4. Joule plugin role 

It is recommended to create three separate single roles for Joule when working in a three-system landscape. The business catalog created in the development system should be included in the DEV-specific role, and the corresponding catalogs for QA and PRD should be added to their respective roles and transported through the landscape. Assigning users the appropriate role for each system ensures that they can see the Joule icon upon logging into the Fiori Launchpad. This approach is essential to ensure that Joule correctly points to the intended BTP subaccount and retrieves data from the corresponding S/4HANA system. 

5. OData services activation 

Based on the required capabilities, identify the corresponding OData services that need to be activated in the system. Activate these services first in the development system, capture them in a transport request, and move the transport to the QA and PRD systems. In some cases, even after the transport is imported, the related ICF services may not be automatically activated in QA or PRD. In such situations, you must manually activate the ICF services. Ensure that the necessary authorizations are available for performing this activation. 

6. Cloud connector principal propagation 

Principal propagations set up in cloud connectors are an important step in Joule configuration. Make sure this is done in Non-Prod and Prod cloud connector.  During production cutover, we must obtain the required access to the production system to check the related parameters, CERTURLE, and certificates in the system. We must ensure access for this and get the fire fighter user if the normal user does not have the required authorization. For most production environments, there will be web dispatchers, and in such cases, we need to import the Cloud Connector certificates into the web dispatchers as well 

7. SSO for Joule 

In most production landscapes, customers expect Single Sign-On (SSO) to be enabled for Joule.  If an S/4HANA system is already configured for SSO using Microsoft Entra ID, you can extend the same setup to Joule by configuring Microsoft Entra ID as the corporate identity provider in SAP IAS and setting it as the default identity provider. Once this is done, SSO for Joule is automatically enabled. Users do not need to exist in the IAS user store for Joule to function, as authentication flows directly through Microsoft Entra ID. 

By taking care of all these steps, you can ensure a smooth and successful Joule implementation across a three-system landscape.

entry.title: Re: SAP Build Workzone Space icons in side menu
entry.content:
MReinert
I know this doesnt answer your question directly but i agree the default icon for all spaces in the side navigation is abit annoying.
We addressed this in a plugin, we wrote our own plugin based on the Space provider, now we have spaces, workpages, and applications in the side navigation all with icons. 
 
Take a look at the Spaces provider class, the icons are configurable for spaces, but it depends on how you configure your spaces, I dont think the Workzone Content Explorer allows you to assign an Icon to a Space.  Therefore if they arent found in your space model (menu) at runtime they will default to what ever you define in the config
this.#oSideNavAPI.getConfigValue("spaces.defaultIcon");
https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/resources/sap/ushell/components/shell/SideNavigation/modules/Spaces-dbg.js
 
Our solution was to write our own plugin, we had a sidenavigation plugin pre Shellbar so not a stretch for us. If you look in the modules folder above there are actually a number of providers in use not just spaces,  eg favorites, recent activities, my home (user configured sidebar) a generic provider which mashes them all up, this gave some good ideas on how to create our plugin which shows spaces - > workpages -> applications all with icons
 
There is a nice simple example of the plugin in the test-resources, if you follow this FixedNavigationListProvider example, its easy to work out the NavigationListProvider and how to infulence the config for the icons etc or read the Graphql CEP API  for Spaces and Workpages -> allVisulizations like we have to get all the viz configs which has the icons to display
https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/test-resources/sap/ushell/demoplugins/UIPluginActionButton/DemoFixedNavigationListProvider.js
 
Hth
John P

entry.title: Re: Not able to access the DL Basket for User
entry.content:
Regarding to your issue, please kindly note that SAP Download Manager does not work with multi-factor authentication (MFA) or SAP Universal ID (UID).

If your S-user is linked to UID, do not enter the UID password in SAP Download Manager. The UID password is the one you use to logon SAP for Me.

Instead, enter your individual S-user ID and Password as mentioned in KBA 3016110. 

If you do not remember the password of your S-user, kindly use below link to reset it. When reset your password, please input the S-user ID instead of email address:

Forgot My Password

Then you will use your download manager normally as before.

You can still use your UID password to logon SAP for Me.

entry.title: SAP Joule Skill for Technical Completion of Maintenance Orders in S/4HANA Asset Management
entry.content:
This blog provides a brief overview of certain advanced functionalities, namely multiple action projects and if-condition expression, within a single JOULE Skill.

What is SAP Joule:

SAP Joule is an AI copilot that is grounded in organization`s business data. It aims to understand our requests, retrieve information, and complete our tasks using natural language in a conversational way.

  • Joule Skill :  It is a predefined capability that executes a specific task within the business context.
  • Joule Agent: It is a more advanced AI powered assistant that uses multiple JOULE Skills and other agents to complete complex tasks/workflows

If you would like a high-level overview of SAP JOULE , and how to setup an SAP JOULE skill using OData services, check out my latest blog post "SAP JOULE & ME : My First JOULE Skill in SAP EHSM-Incident Management Without Coding" by accessing the link below. This blog outlines the basic functionality of the JOULE skill used to create an EHS Incident in the S/4HANA system.

SAP JOULE & ME : My First JOULE Skill in SAP EHSM-Incident Management Without Coding 

My Business Use Case: TECO Maintenance Order with SAP Joule Skill.

In my maintenance procedure, a maintenance order can only be "Technically Closed (TECO)" if the system status contains both REL (Released) & CNF (Confirmed). This ensures that no order is prematurely closed without properly released and confirmed.

To achieve this functionality, I have designed an SAP JOULE skill that leverages:

  • Two Action Projects: This is to get the Maintenance Order Details and Performs Technical Closure.
  • An If Condition: This is to validate if the provided maintenance order has both REL & CNF statuses before allowing the TECO.

This approach enforces strict control mechanism and ensuring that the only valid maintenance orders reach the TECO stage.

Let us break it down step by step to see how this SAP JOULE skill performs the TECO for the maintenance order.

What is an Action Project:

Actions are used in SAP Build Process Automation to connect processes with external systems, be it SAP or Non-SAP system, and to make GET, POST, PATCH calls. The actions that are created here can be consumed directly in a JOULE Skill created in SAP JOULE Studio.

For instance, I have chosen OData V2 API : API_MAINTENANCEORDER for get Maintenance Order details and perform Technical Closure actions.

Now let us test the OData in the action project : EAM_Maintenance_Order_Management.

 

Mini Note: We must follow API guidelines when providing input values. We had better read the business documentation provided under the "Documents" tab in SAP API HUB.

First let us test the GET call : Get Maintenance Order Details by Maintenance Order Number.

Now let us test POST call :  Set Maintenance Order to Technically Completed. 

The API response was successful and status has been updated to TECO.

Once we release and publish the Action project, we can now create JOULE skill in SAP Build Lobby.

Let us setup Input Parameters for "TECO Maintenance Order" Joule skill. This field is used during the conversation with JOULE for TECO of the maintenance order.

As per our business use case, using this input value, i.e., Maintenance Order, we should first get maintenance order status details.

Let us use action project "Get entity from MaintenanceOrder by key" and map the values from the Joule skill input parameters to the action project input value.

If the Maintenance Order Status does not include the system statuses REL (Released) and CNF (Confirmed). the system should display an error message or else It should use the action "Invoke action SetMaintOrdToTechCompleted"

If the condition is satisfied, the system should execute the action project "Invoke action SetMaintOrdToTechCompleted".

As per SAP API documentation, the maintenance order must be enclosed in single quotes when we use POST call "Invoke action SetMaintOrdToTechCompleted".

To achieve this, I have maintained the expression to let the system automatically enclose the provided maintenance order number in singe quotes.

The expression for the condition to close the assigned notification is "true", and for the Maintenance Order, the expression should be as follows.

Now let us configure the "Error Message" when the maintenance order does not satisfy the condition.

For Instance, I have chosen message type as "Illustrated Message".

Now let us configure the "Successful Message" when the maintenance order satisfies the condition.

We can now "Release" and "Deploy" the JOULE skill in respective environment. Once we deploy it, our maintenance team can now interact with JOULE skill in natural language to "Technically Close" the maintenance order.

Let us now interact with JOULE to technically close the maintenance order.

Condition-1: If the system status of the maintenance order does not include the statuses "REL (Released)" & "CNF (Confirmed)", the JOULE skill should provide an error message.

Condition-2: If the system status of the maintenance order includes the statuses "REL (Released)" & "CNF (Confirmed)", the JOULE skill should provide a successful message.

üòäThis brings me to the end of the SAP JOULE skill set up for Technical Completion of the Maintenance Order. Stay tuned for more updates on SAP JOULE skills in Asset Management Space...

Key takeaway:

By combining two action projects with an If condition in a single SAP JOULE skill, we can build more flexible automations that respond to business logic in real time. 

 

--

Yours Sincerely,

Pardhasaradhi Reddy. Chelikam

entry.title: Why Your SAP Upgrades Keep Breaking (And How Event-Driven Architecture Fixes It)
entry.content:
• Why Your SAP Upgrades Keep Breaking (And How Event-Driven Architecture Fixes It)
  • What is a clean core and why it matters
  • Why achieving clean core is hard ?
  • Extensibility as a clean core dimension
  • Event-driven architecture: the clean core enabler
  • Key EDA advantages for SAP landscapes
  • Events as nouns, verbs, and properties
  • Micro integrations: a new, pragmatic integration paradigm
  • How micro integrations support clean core
  • Real-world scenario: business partner events
  • Practical next steps
  • Conclusion

Why Your SAP Upgrades Keep Breaking (And How Event-Driven Architecture Fixes It)

 

If you‚Äôve ever delayed an S/4HANA upgrade because of custom code anxiety, you‚Äôre not alone. Many SAP teams genuinely want to move faster and adopt new innovations , but tightly coupled extensions, brittle integrations, and years of accumulated technical debt often get in the way.

During my session at SAP DevtoberFest 2025 : Clean Core, Event-Driven: Unlocking SAP Value with Advanced Event Mesh 

this challenge came up repeatedly. So, I decided to turn that conversation into a blog . Not as a theoretical exercise, but as a practical guide to one of the most important architectural shifts in modern SAP landscapes: clean core enabled by event-driven architecture (EDA).

What is a clean core and why it matters

A clean core is the strategic foundation for modern SAP landscapes. It means keeping the SAP digital core lean and standard, while moving custom logic, integrations, and nonessential processes to side‚Äëby‚Äëside extensions. This approach reduces upgrade risk, improves performance, lowers operational cost, and makes it possible to adopt new SAP innovations faster and with less friction.

Instead of modifying the core directly, customization happens around it.

Why does this matter? Because a clean core directly translates to:

  • Improved performance: Core resources focus on essential business processes, reducing latency and improving throughput.
  • Higher stability: Fewer custom touch points mean fewer failure surfaces and easier upgrades.
  • Lower maintenance cost: Less bespoke code reduces debugging, regression testing, and emergency fixes.
  • Faster innovation: Standard APIs and modular extensions speed onboarding, refactoring, and new feature delivery.
  • Stay Current: Clean core means reduced complexities and challenges in upgrading to new releases and faster adoption of new features and capabilities

Why achieving clean core is hard ?

If clean core is so clearly beneficial, why isn‚Äôt everyone already there!!??

Because real-world SAP landscapes are messy.

 

Most enterprises face a set of recurring obstacles that erode the clean core ideal:

  • Insufficient extensibility: Legacy systems and older extension points force code changes in the core.
  • Integration complexity: Tightly coupled point-to-point interfaces are fragile to change.
  • Data rot: ROT = Redundant, Obselete and Trivial ‚Äì data in custom fields and tables that erode trust in master data.
  • High upfront investment: Code analysis, data cleanup, and process rework require time and budget before benefits appear.
  • Skills and tooling gaps: Cloud-native extension patterns and event thinking require new skills and practices.
  • Hybrid landscapes: On-prem, multicloud, and different SAP systems introduce compatibility and governance issues.

Extensibility as a clean core dimension

Extensions are inevitable and necessary. The key question isn‚Äôt whether you extend SAP, but how you do it. Clean core demands that:

  • Custom logic must not tamper with core objects
  • Extensions are decoupled from SAP standard
  • Only upgrade-stable mechanisms are used

SAP formalizes this approach through the Clean Core Strategy Pyramid.

The strategy emphasizes a shift away from traditional, "monolithic" customizations that modify the digital core, moving instead toward a side-by-side extensibility model.

By leveraging the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and utilizing stable APIs and events, businesses can decouple their custom logic and integrations from the standard S/4HANA system.

The goal is simple but powerful: Eliminate technical debt and adopt innovation without disruption.

Event-driven architecture: the clean core enabler

Adopting event-driven architecture (EDA) is a practical way to decouple systems and preserve a clean core.

At its heart, EDA treats business changes as events that are published by a source and consumed by one or many subscribers. This replaces brittle point-to-point integrations with a publish/subscribe model where extensions live outside the core.

EDA doesn‚Äôt just support clean core , it actively enforces it.

Key EDA advantages for SAP landscapes

  • Asynchronous communication: Producers and consumers evolve independently.
  • Unlimited fan-out: Publish once, deliver to many subscribers without changing the producer.
  • Scalability and resilience: Brokers absorb bursts and ensure reliable delivery and ordering.
  • Side-by-side extensibility: Consumers implement business logic externally, protecting the core from bespoke changes.

Events as nouns, verbs, and properties

A simple, practical but highly effective way to being with EDA is to visualize business processes as events and further design these events is to describe them with three parts:

  • Noun: the object that changed (for example, BusinessPartner, Order, MaterialMaster, etc).
  • Verb: the change that occurred (created, updated, cancelled, etc.).
  • Properties: attributes that describe the event (IDs, timestamps, locations, reasons).

Micro integrations: a new, pragmatic integration paradigm

Micro integrations are small, single-purpose components that produce or consume events. Think of them as integration-focused microservices: modular, decentralized, and easy to scale. Any component that onloads events to a broker is a source micro integration. Anything that consumes events from a broker is a target micro integration.

How micro integrations support clean core

  • Externalize custom logic: Transformations, validations, and routing live outside SAP core.
  • Reduce coupling: Systems publish events; any number of consumers can subscribe without impacting others.
  • Independent scaling: Deploy micro integrations close to sources or targets and scale them separately.
  • Operational visibility: Centralized monitoring and an event catalog make integrations discoverable and governable.

Real-world scenario: business partner events

Imagine an S/4HANA publishing BusinessPartner created events to a SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh. Instead of hardcoding point-to-point calls, the event is published once and delivered to:

  • A SAP Integration Suite iFlow that pushes partner records to a Salesforce in under 1 second
  • A CAP application that enriches the partner data and makes it available in a cannonical model for other consumers
  • A Snowflake connector which takes SAP events and updates datawarehouse tables for advanced analytics
  • An increasing number of downstream services and funcationalities that bring new business value.

Each of those consumers is a micro integration. They scale independently, can be updated without touching the core, and receive only the events they subscribe to. The result is a leaner S/4HANA core, faster onboarding for new consumers, and more predictable upgrades.

Practical next steps

You don‚Äôt need a big-bang transformation to get started:

  • Identify a single usecase to productize as events (for example, business partner or inventory events).
  • Model each event as Noun-Verb-Properties
  • Start with a source micro integration at the edge to publish, and a single target micro integration to consume.
  • Introduce an event catalog and basic access controls to document ownership and usage rules.
  • Measure event reuse and track the event reuse index to demonstrate value.

Conclusion

Clean core is achievable when extensibility and integrations are treated as products rather than throwaway code.

By combining:

  • Event-driven architecture
  • Micro integrations
  • A governed event mesh

Teams can decouple logic from the SAP core, scale consumption independently, and evolve systems safely over time.

The payoff is real:

  • Fewer upgrade headaches
  • Faster time to value

A more resilient, future-ready SAP landscape

entry.title: What‚Äôs Next for SAP Process Control 12.0 and SAP Risk Management 12.0 ?
entry.content:
What‚Äôs Next for SAP Process Control 12.0 and SAP Risk Management 12.0 ?  This is one of the common questions to most of the Organizations, Leaders, IT Directors, Managers, SMEs, Consultants and Vendors who are currently using SAP Process Control 12.0 and SAP Risk Management 12.0.

Before exploring the next options for SAP Process Control 12.0 and SAP Risk Management 12.0, I recommend referring to the blog below:

What‚Äôs Next for SAP Access Control 12.0?

After reading the above blog, you should now have a clear understanding of the future options for SAP Access Control 12.0.

Option : Upgrade to SAP GRC for HANA 2026 is also applicable to SAP Process Control 12.0 and SAP Risk Management 12.0.

Just as SAP Access Control has the option to ‚ÄúMigrate to SAP Cloud IAG,‚Äù SAP Process Control and SAP Risk Management have the option to ‚ÄúMigrate to SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM).

SAP has introduced a new cloud solution ‚Äî SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM) ‚Äî which is SAP‚Äôs next‚Äëgeneration, cloud‚Äënative platform designed to modernize and unify enterprise risk, controls, and assurance activities, built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).  It is ideal for customers seeking a cloud‚Äëfirst governance, controls, and assurance solution with continuous innovation.

In simple terms, SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM) combines both Process Control (PC) and Risk Management (RM)  capabilities and can be considered the ‚Äúcloud version of PC and RM together.‚Äù

SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM) ‚Äî includes the following key steps:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM) offers below Process Control & Risk Management  equivalent capabilities:

  • Risk Management
  • Control Management
  • Control Execution
  • Result Processing
  • Issue & Remediation Management
  • Reporting

SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM) can seamlessly integrate with below systems

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP S/4HANA On‚ÄëPremise
  • SAP Signavio Integration
  • SAP Analytics Cloud Integration
  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance

Will be creating a new blog on ‚ÄúSAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM) with different options, Pros and Cons, possible options‚Äù, stay tuned for this.

 

#

Scenario

Recommended Solution

Why It Works

1

Long-term on-prem/private-cloud GRC modernization

SAP GRC for HANA 2026

Unified, AI-powered platform; support to 2040

2

Cloud-first strategy (SAP RISE, SAP S/4HANA Cloud etc.)

SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM)

End-to-end cloud based compliance management and Risk Management

Summary

  • Option 1: Upgrade to SAP GRC for HANA 2026
    Ideal for on-premise or private-cloud customers using multiple GRC modules. Also with complex landscape, heavy customization and workflows. Provides a unified, AI-powered platform on SAP HANA with support extended to 2040.
  • Option 2: Migrate to SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM)
    Suits cloud-first organizations on RISE, SAP S/4HANA Private and Public Cloud or other BTP scenarios.  Cloud-based solution built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) to manage risk and compliance efficiently while benefiting from real-time performance, automatic updates, and high system availability.
  • Option 3: Stay on SAP Process Control 12.0 and SAP Risk Management 12.0 (Short-Term)
    Gives organizations extra time for budgeting, complex landscape planning, and team training. Later can choose either Option 1 or Option 2.

Conclusion

Choosing the right path from SAP Process Control 12.0 and SAP Risk Management 12.0 depends on your organization‚Äôs strategy, timeline, and risk profile.  If you‚Äôre committed to on‚Äëpremise GRC and need long‚Äëterm stability, upgrading to SAP GRC for HANA keeps you covered through 2040. For those accelerating cloud adoption, migrating to SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM) delivers a scalable, unified governance and assurance experience. And if you need breathing room to prepare, extending Process Control 12.0 and Risk Management 12.0 in the short term offers continuity without sacrificing compliance.

Whichever route you take, start by mapping your current landscape, aligning stakeholders on priorities, and building a clear project roadmap. Weigh the long‚Äëterm benefits against immediate constraints to make an informed decision that drives both compliance and innovation.

What option works best for your organization? Tell us your GRC challenge in the comments.

Like this post if it helped and subscribe for more SAP GRC blogs, news, tips!

 SAP Process Control  SAP Risk Management  SAP Risk and Assurance Management

entry.title: Re: How to link AUSP-OBJEK and LIFNR
entry.content:
Hi Olga,

You can find the link using table INOB.

You can pass LIFNR with leading zeros (total up to 10 char) e.g. 0000XXXXXX to field OBJEK in table INOB. With "LFA1" to field OBTAB and "010" to field KLART. Get INOB - CUOBJ (unconverted value with leading zeros). INOB - CUOBJ equals AUSP - OBJEK.

Ishara K.

entry.title: Re: value of MCHB-CLABS always returns as 0 in AMDP SQLSc...
entry.content:
In S/4HANA, MCHB is a compatibility view, not a table. While Open SQL handles the redirection automatically, MCHB will appear empty in CDS or AMDP. Use the view NSDM_E_MCHB instead.

When you view MCHB in Eclipse, you can see the name of the replacement object; so you can use this method for other obsolete tables too. Here is a snippet:

@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
@AbapCatalog.replacementObject : 'nsdm_e_mchb'
define table mchb {
  @AbapCatalog.foreignKey.label : 'Client'
  @AbapCatalog.foreignKey.keyType : #KEY
  @AbapCatalog.foreignKey.screenCheck : true
  key mandt : mandt not null
    with foreign key [0..*,1] t000
      where mandt = mchb.mandt;

entry.title: Systems not able to process messages via SAP Cloud Connector as of Q1/2026
entry.content:
Nowadays SAP Cloud Connector is a critical system for customers to process their integrations for their core business processes.

SAP has communicated some months ago about switching to the "DigiCert TLS RSA4096 Root G5" and ‚ÄúDigiCert Global Root G3‚Äù Public Key Infrastructures (PKI). This is only one of the many KBAs created around this topic KBA "3566727 - Root Certificate Replacement in the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Environment" 

Recently we have seen many customers reporting issues regarding Cloud Connector not processing messages.

In Cloud Integration this may be presented as an HTTP response '503: Service Unavailable.' The accompanying error message states: 'org.apache.cxf.interceptor.Fault: Could not send Message., cause: org.apache.cxf.transport.http.HTTPException: HTTP response '503: Service Unavailable. There is no SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) connected to your subaccount matching the requested tunnel for subaccount.'"

Customers get confused, because the Cloud Connector displays that the subaccount is connected.

On BTP Cockpit, they also see the Cloud Connector. 

However, the messages sent to be processed via this Cloud Connector still fail. 

How to find the cause?

Set the traces as per the following:

Reproduce the issue and download the "scc_core.trc" trace file. Then revert the trace settings as before.

Inside the file "scc_core.trc", look for string "PKIX path building failed: sun.security.provider.certpath.SunCertPathBuilderException: unable to find valid certification path to requested target."

For example:

Your issue is likely caused because of a missing certificate. Check this KBA "3583377 - Cloud Connector will fail to connect to subaccount"

The certificates come with the JVM, review and ensure you have at least the versions below:

  • SAP JVM 8.1.097
  • SapMachine 11.0.22 (SapMachine 11 is out of maintenance, though)
  • SapMachine 17.0.10
  • SapMachine 21.0.2
  • Oracle JDK 8u401

If your version is under the ones mentioned above, update as per this documentation https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/update-java-vm.

This solve resolve your issue, if not, you may open an incident with BC-MID-SCC.

Best Regards,
Victor
